This will also bring down the traversal time at the airports," the minister was quoted as saying in a statement.<br><br>He elaborated that at the same time, security concerns will continue to get the highest priority to ensure Indian skies are kept safe and vibrant.<br><br>The week-long trial run for all domestic passengers was initiated by the Bureau of Civil Aviation Security (BCAS) at six airports namely Mumbai, Delhi, Hyderabad, Bengaluru, Kolkata and Ahmedabad.<br><br>"Based on the advice of the Ministry of Civil Aviation, BCAS had initiated a pilot project in collaboration with Hyderabad International Airport Limited and CISF for non-stamping of baggage tag in one of the lanes at Hyderabad airport," the statement disclosed.<br><br>"After the successful completion of the effort, BCAS has advised to do away with the stamping of hand baggage's tag for implementing the best practice adopted internationally for hassle free movement of passengers."<br><br>The statement pointed out that up on the success of the trial run, the same practice will be extended to other airports.<br><br>"To strengthen the security screening of baggage, high-resolution CCTV cameras and other appropriate technologies have been adopted by the airport operators as advised by the BCAS," the statement added.<br><br>--IANS<br>ppg-rv/vt</p>

item.title: Pawars save bastion Baramati in local polls
item.description: Mumbai, Dec 15 (IANS) Nationalist Congress Party top leaders -- Sharad Pawar, daughter Supriya Sule and nephew Ajit Pawar -- managed to defend their home bastion against an onslaught led by the BJP and others, and bagged 35 of the 39 seats in Baramati Municipal Council elections.,
item.content: Mumbai, Dec 15 (IANS) Nationalist Congress Party top leaders -- Sharad Pawar, daughter Supriya Sule and nephew Ajit Pawar -- managed to defend their home bastion against an onslaught led by the BJP and others, and bagged 35 of the 39 seats in Baramati Municipal Council elections.,<p><br><br>In a major relief to the state's numero uno political family, Baramati in Pune district returned 35 NCP candidates and four Independents in election results declared on Thursday. All other political parties drew a blank. NCP candidate Purnima Tawde was elected council President.<br><br>Elsewhere, in elections to 14 municipal bodies, results of which also were announced on Thursday, the Bharatiya Janata Party bagged five posts of council Presidents and 81 of the total 324 seats contested.<br><br>The NCP bounced back with a total of 93 seats and two posts of council Presidents, including Baramati in Pune district and Ausa in Latur.<br><br>The Congress performance was a notch lower with a total of 45 seats and two posts of council Presidents -- Indapur and Jejuri, both in Pune district.<br><br>The Shiv Sena came fourth by netting 23 seats and one council presidentship in Junnar.<br><br>Independents and smaller state parties put up unexpectedly good performance by bagging four council Presidents' posts, including an Independent who will head the Daund council, and bagged 82 seats.<br><br>Hyderabad-based All India Majlis-e-Ittehad-ul Muslimeen of Asaduddin Owaisi bagged six seats in Udgir, Latur, where a BJP nominee was elected the council President.<br><br>The Shirur Vikas Aghadi bagged the council President's post and 12 seats in Shirur, where Independents won seven and the BJP two seats.<br><br>In Saswad, the Janmat Vikas Aghadi bagged the council President's post and 17 of the 19 seats. The remaining two went to the Shiv Sena.<br><br>The Bahujan Vikas Aghadi bagged the Ahmedpur Municipal Council President's post plus four seats. The NCP bagged nine of the 23 seats, the BJP six and the Congress and the Shiv Sena two each.<br><br>In the second phase of the ongoing elections to the municipal councils, 14 local bodies in Pune and Latur districts went to the polls on Wednesday, results of which were declared on Thursday.<br><br>--IANS<br>qn/tsb/vt</p>

item.title: Bhutan banks to be supplied with new Indian currency: Official
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) In response to a request from Bhutan, where Indian currency is legal tender, the Reserve Bank of India has instructed that banks in that country be replenished with new Indian currency notes, a senior official said on Thursday.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) In response to a request from Bhutan, where Indian currency is legal tender, the Reserve Bank of India has instructed that banks in that country be replenished with new Indian currency notes, a senior official said on Thursday.<p><br><br>Economic Affairs Secretary Shaktikanta Das told reporters here that a committee has been set up to examine the issue of supplying new rupee banknotes to neighbouring Nepal and Bhutan where Indian currency is legal tender.<br><br>He said that on the request of Bhutan in the matter, the RBI has issued instructions for replenishment of new Indian currency stocks in the banks in Bhutan.<br><br>The committee concerned is, however, yet to take a decision on Indian currency replenishments for banks in Nepal.<br><br>The Indian government announced the demonetisation of high-value notes on November 8 in a bid to curb black money, counterfeting and terror financing.<br><br>--IANS<br>bc/vd <br></p>

item.title: Indian exports at $20 bn in November grow 2.3% over last year (Lead)
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Signalling a definitive reversal of the continuous decline in Indian exports earlier in the year, official data on Thursday showed these grew for the third month in a row at $20 billion in November, an uptick of 2.29 per cent over $19.56 billion in November 2015.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Signalling a definitive reversal of the continuous decline in Indian exports earlier in the year, official data on Thursday showed these grew for the third month in a row at $20 billion in November, an uptick of 2.29 per cent over $19.56 billion in November 2015.<p><br><br>Data released by the Commerce Ministry showed that the pace of increase of exports in November, however, slowed sequentially from the 9.59 per cent growth in October at $23.51 billion worth of merchandise exports that month.<br><br>Cumulatively for the April-November period, exports rose marginally by 0.1 per cent in dollar terms at $174.9 billion, as against exports of $174.7 billion over the same period last year.<br><br>The government said there was growth in exports for US (0.25 per cent) and Japan (9.81 per cent) but China and EU exhibited negative growth of (-10.15 per cent) and (-0.57 per cent) respectively for September 2016 over the corresponding period of previous year, as per latest WTO statistics.<br> <br>"Non-petroleum exports in November 2016 were valued at $17.60 billion against $17.23billion in November 2015, an increase of 2.1 per cent," a statement here said.<br><br>Imports during the month in question at $33.02 billion, were 10.44 per cent higher than the imports of $29.90 billion in October 2015.<br><br>Consequently, the trade deficit in November this year was $13 billion, as compared to the deficit of $10.34 billion during same month last year.<br><br>The wider deficit could pressure on the rupee at a time when there is a risk of global investors pulling capital out of risky emerging markets, attracted by the interest rate hike by the US federal reserve on Wednesday<br><br>Cumulative imports for April-November were worth more than $241.1 billion, which was a 8.44 per cent fall from over $263.31 billion worth imports recorded for the same period a year ago.<br><br>With global oil prices climbing back over $50 a barrel levels, India's oil imports during November 2016 were valued at $6.84 billion, which was 5.89 per cent higher than oil imports valued at $6.46 billion in the corresponding period last year.<br><br>Non-oil imports in November rose by 11.70 per cent to $26.18 billion, from $23.44 billion in the same month of last year<br><br>The trade deficit cumulatively for April-November, however, declined to $66.18 billion against $88.57 billion in the same period of 2015-16.<br><br>As per Reserve Bank of India data on Thursday, services exports during October 2016 were valued at $13.113 billion, registering a fall of 4.79 per cent in dollar terms as compared to positive growth of 2.93 per cent in the ptrevious month.<br><br>Taking merchandise and services together, overall trade deficit for April-November 2016 is estimated at $28.38 billion, which is 41.11 per cent lower in dollar terms than the level of $48.20 billion during the same period last year.<br><br>--IANS<br>bc/vd <br></p>

item.title: Gujarat bans hookah bars
item.description: Gandhinagar, Dec 15 (IANS) The Gujarat government on Thursday approved an ordinance to ban hookah bars across the state. The decision was taken at a meeting of the State Cabinet chaired by Chief Minister Vijay Rupani.
item.content: Gandhinagar, Dec 15 (IANS) The Gujarat government on Thursday approved an ordinance to ban hookah bars across the state. The decision was taken at a meeting of the State Cabinet chaired by Chief Minister Vijay Rupani.<p><br><br>"From today, it will be a cognisable offence to operate a hookah bar in the state. The penalty for running the bar would be imprisonment of one to three years and fine between Rs 20,000 and Rs 50,000," state Home Minister Pradipsinh Jadeja told rporters here.<br><br>The Gujarat Police had earlier forced several hookah bars across the state to shut down over the issue of license. However, the hookah bar owners challenged the action in the courts, which ruled in their favour. After this, the bars re-opened and many more mushroomed in several cities.<br><br>Jadeja said the government had brought in the provision because many youngsters were falling prey to the habit and getting into debt. "Eventually some of them got involved in anti-social behaviour. It became a matter of concern."<br><br>--IANS<br>desai/vgu/vt</p>

item.title: Congress responsible for Parliament impasse: Minister
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Union Parliamentary Affairs Minister Ananth Kumar on Thursday held the Congress responsible for the Parliament impasse and said the opposition party did not want to debate demonetisation in both the houses.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Union Parliamentary Affairs Minister Ananth Kumar on Thursday held the Congress responsible for the Parliament impasse and said the opposition party did not want to debate demonetisation in both the houses.<p><br><br>"From Day One, they pursued a confused and disjointed strategy in both the houses. In the Rajya Sabha, where their numbers are more, they did not have any condition for the debate on the first day. In the Lok Sabha, where their numbers are less, they wanted a voting," Ananth Kumar said.<br><br>"The whole debate was lost to the myopic strategy of the Congress leadership and its Vice-President Rahul Gandhi..." he said.<br><br>"There was a lot for the government to say and a lot of things for the oppostition to raise, criticise and analyse," the minister said.<br><br>Another senior minister, on the condition of anonymity, blamed the Congress Vice-President for "gagging" Parliament.<br><br>"In every BAC (Business Advisory Committee) meeting, time was allocated for bills, for the supplementary demand for grants and other topics. But the opposition did not let the house function. Rahul Gandhi is the mastermind behind the gagging of Parliament; the only other time it has happened was in 1975-76," the minister said.<br><br>The government, meanwhile, is hopeful of getting the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Bill, 2014, passed in the Lok Sabha on Friday, with the opposition giving "positive signals" towards this end, informed sources said.<br><br>Friday is the last day of the winter session, which began on November 16, and the signals from both the government and opposition sides indicate that Parliament may not function properly, just as was the case with the rest of the session.<br><br>The winter session of Parliament is headed for a washout due to continued disruptions over demonetisation and other issues.<br><br>--IANS<br>ao/tsb/vt</p>

item.title: RBI holds its 562nd central board meet in Kolkata
item.description: Kolkata, Dec 15 (IANS) Amidst demonetisation row, the Reserve Bank of India on Thursday reviewed the current economic situation, global and domestic challenges and other specific areas of operations in its 562nd central board meet here.
item.content: Kolkata, Dec 15 (IANS) Amidst demonetisation row, the Reserve Bank of India on Thursday reviewed the current economic situation, global and domestic challenges and other specific areas of operations in its 562nd central board meet here.<p><br><br>The meeting was chaired by the apex bank's governor Urjit Patel.<br><br>"The Board reviewed the current economic situation, global and domestic challenges and other specific areas of operations of the Reserve Bank of India," a statement said.<br><br>After the board meet, Patel met West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee and state government officials to discuss "region specific issues".<br><br>Besides RBI's Deputy Governors R. Gandhi, S.S. Mundra and N.S.Vishwanathan, the other directors of the central board, Natarajan Chandrasekaran, Bharat Doshi and Sudhir Mankad were present at the meeting.<br><br>The meeting was also attended by Government nominee director on the central board, Anjuly Chib Duggal, Secretary, Financial Services in the Finance Ministry.<br><br>--IANS<br>bdc/vd<br><br><br><br></p>

item.title: Czech Foreign Minister to visit India
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Czech Foreign Minister Lubomir Zaoralek, accompanied by a 30-member delegation including 18 businessmen, will be on a visit to India December 18-20, the Ministry of External Affairs said on Thursday.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Czech Foreign Minister Lubomir Zaoralek, accompanied by a 30-member delegation including 18 businessmen, will be on a visit to India December 18-20, the Ministry of External Affairs said on Thursday.<p><br><br>"He is scheduled to hold delegation level talks with M.J. Akbar, Minister of State for External Affairs on December 19 on bilateral and multilateral issues. He is also expected to meet other Ministers in the Ministries of Heavy Industries, Commerce and Defence," said MEA spokesperson Vikas Swarup in his weekly media briefing. <br><br>On the bilateral relations, he said: "Regular exchanges of high level visit have taken place from both sides. India and Czech Republic have strong linkage in all fields i.e. political, economic & commercial, defence, science and technology, culture, tourism and people to people exchange." <br><br>Czech Deputy Defence Minister Tomas Kuchta visited India in March this year, while then Minister of State for External Affairs Preneet Kaur visited Czech Republic in 2012. Last visit of the Czech Foreign Minister to India was in 2013.<br><br>On trade relations between India and Czech Republic, Swarup said: "Our bilateral trade is estimated at $1.2 billion with much untapped potential."<br><br>Indian Investors such as Infosys, Tata Tea, Alok Industries, Glen Mark Pharmaceuticals, Cafe Coffee day have made sizable investment in the Czech Republic and Czech companies such as Skoda Auto, Skoda Power, Bonatrans and Home Credit have investments in India.<br><br>--IANS<br>rs-vd</p>

item.title: Government to reimburse MDR charges on taxes payments by cards
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The Union Government will reimburse banks Merchant Discount Rate (MDR) charges on taxes and receipts paid through debit and credit cards, an official statement on Thursday.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The Union Government will reimburse banks Merchant Discount Rate (MDR) charges on taxes and receipts paid through debit and credit cards, an official statement on Thursday.<p><br><br>"In a bid to encourage digital transactions, budgetary provision will be made to reimburse MDR charges to banks on taxes and other government receipts paid via debit and credit cards," said a Finance Ministry circular. <br><br>The provision will be made under the account head in the Demand for Grants of the Department of Economic Affairs for payment of MDR charges on all receipts of the government.<br><br>"The banks receiving government dues like tax revenue and other receipts through debit/credit cards will submit the claims of MDR charges to the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) periodically," the circular said.<br><br>The RBI will reimburse banks' claims of MDR charges on receipt transactions through credit to the bank and debit the government as per the budget provision.<br><br>The government recently waived service charges on card payments up to Rs 2,000 after scrapping higher denomination notes on November 8.<br><br>--IANS<br>fb/vd</p>

item.title: Scope of double-counting in deposits, says government
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The government on Thursday accepted the possibility of double-counting of the deposits received in the old Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 notes by the banking system, and added that the verification process is on.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The government on Thursday accepted the possibility of double-counting of the deposits received in the old Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 notes by the banking system, and added that the verification process is on.<p><br><br>"We think there is scope of double counting, so the verification is continuing," Economic Affairs Secretary Shaktikanta Das told reporters here.<br><br>"We have identified areas where double counting could have been possible. The banks are checking and re-checking to see there is double counting of figures," Das added.<br><br>The possibility of double-counting of deposits was fuelled in wake of huge deposit figures being quoted by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).<br><br>RBI had earlier reported that Rs 12.44 lakh crore of demonetised Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 notes have been deposited till December 10 by the public since the demonetisation announced on November 8. <br><br>The government had earlier said the total amount of high denomination currency circulating in the system on November 8 - the day of demonetisation - was Rs 15.44 lakh crore or $225 billion (Rs 8.58 lakh crore in Rs 500 notes and Rs 6.86 lakh crore in Rs 1,000).<br><br>With still a fortnight remaining for the people to deposit their cash in old notes, it is thus being widely expected that the reported amount will exceed way beyond the Rs 15.44 lakh crore, as an outcome of double-counting by the banks. <br><br>--IANS<br>mm/vd</p>

item.title: Demonetisation a fiasco, says CPI-M
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The "surgical strike" of demonetisation on black money and corruption has turned out to be a fiasco "coupled with a scam on an industrial scale", the CPI-M has said.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The "surgical strike" of demonetisation on black money and corruption has turned out to be a fiasco "coupled with a scam on an industrial scale", the CPI-M has said.<p><br><br>An editorial in the party journal "People's Democracy" said that 36 days after the withdrawal of the 500 and 1,000 rupee notes, ordinary people were struggling to get meagre amounts of cash from their own bank accounts or ATMs. <br><br>"Long queues and endless wait outside banks and ATMs continue. There is no cash available for those who need it the most - the casual labourer, the vegetable vendor, the domestic worker and the whole workforce involved in the informal economy," it said.<br><br>The Communist Party of India-Marxist, however, pointed out that at the same time, large amounts of new notes were being found in the hands of businessmen, hawala operators, politicians and corrupt bureaucrats. <br><br>"The last two weeks have seen income tax raids which have uncovered huge amounts of unaccounted money and that too in brand new 2,000 rupee notes...<br><br>"According to one estimate, around Rs 160 crore of new notes were seized from all over the country up to December 12 and this is only the tip of the iceberg." <br><br>The editorial went on: "What we are witnessing is a money laundering operation on a grand scale. Instead of curbing black money, what (Prime Minister Narendra) Modi's demonetisation has achieved is to get large amounts of black money converted into white money. <br><br>"It has opened new avenues of corruption in the financial system. Corrupt bank officials are conniving with money launderers to make the exchange of notes a large-scale scam. <br><br>The government has been clueless on how to check this money laundering through the banks using various devices." <br><br>It said the "cashless economy" slogan was being pushed to cover up the fact that the government had miserably failed to produce adequate amounts of new currency notes. <br><br>"The 'cashless' drive is thus a bid to divert attention from the currency disaster facing the country."<br><br>--IANS<br>mr/vd</p>

item.title: 19 persons booked in Delhi for cash seizures after demonetisation
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Four cases were registered against 19 persons in connection with seizure of Rs 17.81 crore in demonetised and new currency notes in the past around three weeks, the Delhi Police said on Thursday.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Four cases were registered against 19 persons in connection with seizure of Rs 17.81 crore in demonetised and new currency notes in the past around three weeks, the Delhi Police said on Thursday.<p><br><br>The four First Information Reports (FIRs) were registered against 19 people -- including businessmen, hawala traders, property dealers and their employees -- on charges of cheating, criminal conspiracy, criminal breach of trust by public servant etc. <br><br>Ten of the accused have been arrested while nine are still to be traced.<br><br>"We have, till now, seized Rs 17.81 crore in raids conducted at different locations across the national capital since November 24 and registered four FIRs," Joint Commissioner of Police (Crime Branch) Ravindra Yadav said. <br><br>The officer said the seizures included Rs 2.98 crore in new currency notes. <br><br>On Tuesday, a joint team of the Delhi Police Crime Branch and Income Tax Department raided Hotel Taksh Inn in west Delhi's Karol Bagh and Chhawla areas and seized Rs 3.89 crore, including Rs 11 lakh in new notes. <br><br>On December 11, during searches at a law firm in Greater Kailash in south Delhi, a Crime Branch team seized Rs 13.65 crore, including Rs 2.60 crore in new notes. The law firm is owned by businessman Rohit Tondon. <br><br>The Crime Branch officials seized Rs 27 lakh in new currency and arrested two men during a raid on November 24 at the Hazrat Nizamuddin railway station. <br><br>--IANS<br>sp-rak/tsb/vt</p>

item.title: AAI airports asked to shift to e-payments for parking: Sinha
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The union government on Thursday informed Parliament that state-owned Airports Authority of India (AAI) has issued directions to respective 'car parking licensees' across all AAI-controlled airports to evolve a mechanism for e-payment transactions.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The union government on Thursday informed Parliament that state-owned Airports Authority of India (AAI) has issued directions to respective 'car parking licensees' across all AAI-controlled airports to evolve a mechanism for e-payment transactions.<p><br><br>According to Minister of State for Civil Aviation Jayant Sinha, car parking licensees at AAI controlled airports have been asked to evolve a mechanism of e-payment transactions in the form of debit or credit cards, digital wallets.<br><br>The minister informed the Lok Sabha, that car parking licensees have also been asked to keep sufficient change of currency in small denomination of Rs 10, Rs 20, Rs 50 and Rs 100 to smoothen the process of parking at all airports. <br><br>"AAI is evolving a mechanism so that digital payment alternatives through various modes is available at all concessions providing passenger facilitation services at airports (such as food and beverage outlets, general retails, car rentals, pre-paid taxi services," Sinha was quoted as saying in a written reply to a question in the Lok Sabha. <br><br>--IANS<br>rv/vt</p>

item.title: President Mukherjee emphasises women empowerment
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) President Pranab Mukherjee on Thursday stressed the necessity of educating women, providing them economic independence, and legal rights and social awareness for their empowerment.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) President Pranab Mukherjee on Thursday stressed the necessity of educating women, providing them economic independence, and legal rights and social awareness for their empowerment.<p><br><br>The President expressed his views while meeting a delegation from Young FICCI Ladies Organisation (YFLO) at Rashtrapati Bhavan.<br> <br>Speaking on the occasion, Mukherjee congratulated the YFLO for its enthusiasm and encouragement to an important cause and said "a society which cannot respect women cannot be called a civilised society". <br><br>Outlining the steps to empower women, he said the first and foremost necessity was education of women, which would help them to understand their problems and develop in them consciousness to look for solutions. <br><br>He mentioned economic independence as the second necessity to make women independent. <br><br>"On many occasions, the economic value of the contribution of women is not highlighted. The contribution of women is also not highlighted through services which are not accounted for in economic terms. This should be changed," the President said. <br><br>He described legal rights granted to women through various laws as the third aspect which is important for their empowerment. <br><br>Mukherjee said that creation of social awareness in this regard, is the fourth necessity. <br><br>"The need was for involvement of all sections of society in order to sensitize people to give women their due and empower them. It was necessary to change the mental frame and do away with prejudices," he said. <br><br>The President also emphasised that it was necessary to avoid "tokenism", and said that though this may seem like a long and arduous journey but success could be achieved through commitment and sustained efforts. <br><br>--IANS<br>rak/vgu/vt</p>

item.title: \'Luv Ka The End\': Splitsville time in Bollywood, Hollywood (2016 In Retrospect)
item.description: Mumbai, Dec 15 (IANS) For years, the world of showbiz has set popular benchmarks for love and romance. But away from the reel, real life love stories went sour for multiple celebrity couples across the Bollywood and Hollywood circuit in 2016, which also interestingly brought in Hindi cinema\'s very own \"Breakup song\".
item.content: Mumbai, Dec 15 (IANS) For years, the world of showbiz has set popular benchmarks for love and romance. But away from the reel, real life love stories went sour for multiple celebrity couples across the Bollywood and Hollywood circuit in 2016, which also interestingly brought in Hindi cinema\'s very own \"Breakup song\". <p>Their personal lives hogged limelight through the gossip columns and had the social media world buzzing. IANS has compiled a mix of splits that left fans and fraternity members wonder about what went wrong: * Actor-filmmaker Farhan Akhtar and celebrity hairstylist Adhuna Bhabani: They called it quits after 16 years of marriage, announcing that they had \"mutually and amicably decided to separate\". It was not revealed why the parents of two children -- Akira and Shakya -- decided to split, but several rumours indicated that an actress could have been home-breaker for this love saga. * Actor-filmmaker Arbaaz Khan and actress Malaika Arora: The speculation about tensions between the couple had been on for a while, but it was in March that Arbaaz and Malaika decided to announce that they were on a \"break\". And in November, they applied for divorce -- just months after they co-hosted \"Power Couple\", a reality TV show based on love and positivity. Together, Arbaaz and Malaika, who got married in 1997, and always complemented each other with their looks, have a 14-year-old son named Arhaan. * Actors Sushant Singh Rajput and Ankita Lokhande: He made the girl go weak in the knees when he proposed to her on one knee on national television. But alas, the love story didn\'t last long. Having made their acting debut in 2009 with the TV show \"Pavitra Rishta\", Sushant and Ankita were quickly pronounced one of best looking TV couples at one point of time. He was offered \"Kai Po Che!\", which put him on a roll in Bollywood, reportedly taking a toll on his relationship with Ankita, who is also said to have been insecure. After a six-year long romance, Sushant had announced in January 2016 that he would tie the knot with Ankita by the end of this year. But their relationship took another course. * Actors Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie: Labelled as the split of all splits of 2016, the Brangelina breakup rocked the entertainment world like none other, leaving their fans heartbroken. Jolie cited \"irreconcilable differences\" as the grounds for the divorce, while Pitt released a statement of his own to People magazine saying: \"I am very saddened by this, but what matters most now is the well-being of our kids.\" The two got together in 2004 after starring in \"Mr & Mrs Smith\", leading to the latter\'s split from \"Friends\" star Jennifer Aniston. They got married in 2014 in France, and have six children together. * Actors Johnny Depp and Amber Heard: This was one split which got a tad ugly with actress Heard\'s allegation that she was physically and verbally abused by Depp throughout their relationship. She divorced the \"Pirates of the Caribbean\" star in May. Their love saga began with their meeting on the set of \"The Rum Diary\" in 2009, and they started dating in 2012. It was in February 2015 that they exchanged wedding vows, but sources close to the couple said their fights began within three months. * Actor Pulkit Samrat and Shweta Rohira: \"Fukrey\" actor Pulkit Samrat\'s split with Salman Khan\'s \'Rakhi sister\' Shweta Rohira, could also be counted among splits that caught the attention this year -- given the \"Dabangg\" star\'s connect. The split came two years after their marriage, and blamed for the split was Pulkit\'s \"Sanam Re\" and \"Junooniyat\" co-star Yami Gautam. However, the truth of the matter remains a mystery. (Durga Chakravarty can be contacted at durga.c@ians.in <mailto:durga.c@ians.in>) --IANS dc/rb/vm</p>

item.title: Indo-European joint funding for life science meetings
item.description: Kolkata, Dec 15 (IANS) The European Molecular Biology Organization (EMBO) and the Wellcome Trust/DBT India Alliance will partner to jointly fund up to three life science meetings per year in India, a statement said on Thursday.
item.content: Kolkata, Dec 15 (IANS) The European Molecular Biology Organization (EMBO) and the Wellcome Trust/DBT India Alliance will partner to jointly fund up to three life science meetings per year in India, a statement said on Thursday.<p><br><br>The partnership aims to catalyze a high level of discussion and identify new areas of interdisciplinary life sciences research for India.<br><br>In a statement, the EMBO said the meetings should address "discovery and innovation through an interdisciplinary approach, with the speakers and participants discussing important global challenges in the context of the life sciences".<br><br>The meetings will include 10 to 15 highly acclaimed international speakers and 50 to 75 participants, allowing early to mid-career scientists to interact with leading international experts during a period of three days.<br><br>"Proceedings from the meeting should be drafted as a position paper to advise the India Alliance regarding this area of research. The paper should in particular outline if and how research covered by the meeting could be beneficial to India," the statement said, adding India Alliance may consider increasing funding for research in that area following expert advice and review.<br><br>"We hope this partnership will catalyze a high level of discussion and identify new areas of interdisciplinary life sciences research for India. We also hope that early career Indian researchers will benefit from the company of visionary science leaders at these meetings," said Chief Executive Officer of Wellcome Trust/DBT India Alliance Shahid Jameel.<br><br>--IANS<br>sgh/vgu/vt</p>

item.title: Wadia questions acquisitions made by Tata Chemicals
item.description: Mumbai, Dec 15 (IANS) Ahead of the December 23 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) called for his removal as independent director of Tata Chemicals Ltd (TCL), Nusli Wadia said on Thursday that he and other board members expressed concerns over acquisition of the Brunner Mond Group for Rs 800 crore and merger of HLCL (Haldia Plant) with the company.
item.content: Mumbai, Dec 15 (IANS) Ahead of the December 23 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) called for his removal as independent director of Tata Chemicals Ltd (TCL), Nusli Wadia said on Thursday that he and other board members expressed concerns over acquisition of the Brunner Mond Group for Rs 800 crore and merger of HLCL (Haldia Plant) with the company.<p><br><br>"I as well as some other Board members expressed serious apprehensions on the proposal for the acquisition of the Brunner Mond Group, having soda ash business operation in UK, Keneya (Magadi Soda) and Netherlands at a cost of around Rs 800 crore for sound reasons," Wadia said in representation to shareholders of the company.<br><br>He said the board members had expressed concerns on the fundamental issues involved in the overall arrangement, the risk involved and the assumptions and projections made for profitability.<br><br>They doubted the rate of return as envisaged in the proposal, the letter said.<br><br>In the 12-page representation to shareholders in which Wadia appealed to them to vote against his removal as an independent director, he also said that the acquisition decision was taken by consensus but profitability became negative and continued to remain so after the same (acquisition).<br><br>"I differed strongly in the proposal for the merger of HLCL (Haldia plant) with the company, which involved an investment to the tune of Rs 347 crore," he said.<br><br>Further, Wadia said that he raised serious concerns over the year for "providing continuing financial resources" of the company towards the "overseas businesses and assets" which were continuously "underperforming and incurring substantial losses".<br><br>"This has now led to an impairment on this acquisition of approximately Rs 1,600 crore," he said.<br><br>Wadia mentioned that the company is currently looking to extricate itself from substantial part of its Britain business including the pension fund issues which it has inherited from the acquisition. <br><br>He also said during the last 10 years mainly due to various acquisitions, the consolidated debt of the company went up from Rs 1,827 crore to Rs 8,695 crore, an increase of Rs 6,800 crore.<br><br>"This included the funding required for other joint ventures and subsidiaries. The total impairment of all the various investments made is approximately Rs 2,000 crore," he added.<br><br>--IANS<br>bdc/vd</p>

item.title: BJP leaders arrested for bringing out rally against Muslim cleric's 'fatwa'
item.description: Kolkata, Dec 15 (IANS) Several senior BJP leaders were arrested on Thursday while they brought out a rally protesting a "fatwa" issued by a Muslim cleric against state party chief Dilip Gosh for his "derogatory" remarks against state Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee.
item.content: Kolkata, Dec 15 (IANS) Several senior BJP leaders were arrested on Thursday while they brought out a rally protesting a "fatwa" issued by a Muslim cleric against state party chief Dilip Gosh for his "derogatory" remarks against state Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee.<p><br><br>Shahi Imam of Tipu Sultan Mosque Maulana Noor-ur Rahman Barkati gave the "fatwa" on Monday against Ghosh who had termed Banerje as "semi-mad" and said she could have been "held by her hair" and thrown out by the BJP government if it so desired when the Chief Minister held a demonstration at Delhi's Jantar Mantar against demonetisation last month.<br><br>The rally, organised to condemn Barakti, started close to the BJP state office in central Kolkata, with the BJP earlier declaring it would end outside the Tipu Sultan Mosque.<br><br>To prevent any untoward incidents, police put up barricades on Central Avenue and asked the BJP leaders including Ghosh not to proceed, but as they refused to listen, police arrested them.<br><br>The BJP leaders, however, alleged that police had used "brute force" to stop the "peaceful rally" and called it yet another instance of the Banerjee government's "politics of appeasement".<br><br>A BJP leader claimed that Ghosh was injured when police tried to forcibly stop the rallyists. BJP state lawmaker Swadhin Sarkar and its state general secretary Deboshree Chowdhury, besides actor-turned politician Locket Chatterjee were arrested.<br><br>--IANS<br>ssp/vd<br><br><br><br><br></p>

item.title: 55 trains delayed, 16 cancelled due to fog (Lead)
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Thousands of passengers were stranded on Thursday as 55 trains were delayed and 17 cancelled due to dense fog in parts of north India.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Thousands of passengers were stranded on Thursday as 55 trains were delayed and 17 cancelled due to dense fog in parts of north India.<p><br><br>According to a Northern Railway official, the Mau-Anand Vihar Express was running 33 hours behind schedule, the Lichchvi Express was running 28 hours behind and the Bhagalpur-Anand Vihar Garib Rath was 22 hours late.<br><br>The official also said that at least 13 trains running on Thursday were cancelled while four trains scheduled to depart on Friday were also cancelled. <br><br>Major trains cancelled on Thursday included New Delhi-Rajendra Nagar Rajdhani Express, New Delhi-Bhubaneshwar Duranto Express, Bhubaneshwar-New Delhi Rajdhani Express, New Delhi-Hyderabad Express, Manikpur-Nizamuddin UP Sampark Kranti, New Delhi-Islampur Magadh Express and New Delhi-Jay Nagar Swatantrata Senani Express.<br><br>Major trains cancelled on Friday included New Delhi-Puri Neelanchal Express, Haridwar-Una Himachal Link, Sitamarhi-Anand Vihar Terminal Lichhavi Express and Amritsar-Darbhanga Jannayak Express.<br><br>The official said that 23 trains were rescheduled as the visibility dropped to 400 metres on Thursday.<br><br>Meanwhile, according to the Delhi International Airport Limited (DIAL), which manages operations at the Indira Gandhi International (IGI) airport here, no flight was cancelled on Thursday.<br><br>--IANS<br>aks/vd</p>

item.title: India beat Spain to enter semis of Hockey Junior World Cup (Lead)
item.description: Lucknow, Dec 15 (IANS) Home favourites India overcame Spain 2-1 to set up a semi-final clash against Australia in the Hockey Junior World Cup at the Major Dhyan Chand Stadium here on Thursday.
item.content: Lucknow, Dec 15 (IANS) Home favourites India overcame Spain 2-1 to set up a semi-final clash against Australia in the Hockey Junior World Cup at the Major Dhyan Chand Stadium here on Thursday.<p><br><br>Marc Serrahima's successful penalty conversion had given Spain a 1-0 lead in the 22nd minute. But India fought back in the second half with penalty corner conversions from Simranjeet Singh (57th) and Harmanpreet Singh (66th) to march into the last four stage.<br><br>After this win, Harendra Singh-coached India will face the task of going past Australia, who got the better of European powerhouse the Netherlands 2-1.<br><br>The last time India reached the semi-final of the tournament was in 2005 in Rotterdam. They had finished fourth then.<br><br>The other semi-final will be played between double defending champion Germany and Belgium. While Germany eased past England 4-2, Belgium edged past Argentina 4-1 (1-1) via penalty shoot-out.<br><br>The match between India and Spain turned out to be a tough fight and the European team stifled the hosts with strong man-to-man marking. Spain curbed India's flair and managed to keep them at bay.<br><br>India got a couple of penalty corners but due to technical flaws like poor trapping and bad execution, they were not fruitful.<br><br>Spain, meanwhile took the lead after earning a penalty corner in the 22nd minute. Serrahima's powerful flick to the right low corner beat Indian goalkeeper Vikash Dahiya to give Spain a 1-0 lead, much to the frustration of the decent crowd in attendance.<br><br>Spain managed to keep their lead till the half-time and in the second half, it seemed the equaliser was difficult to come by as the Indians kept making a mess of penalty corner opportunities.<br><br>But in the 57th minute, it changed. Even though it was a poorly executed penalty corner, Sumit managed to hit a powerful blow straight at the Spanish goalkeeper Albert Perez, who blocked it before the ball popped out. Simranjeet tapped the ball in quickly before the goalkeeper could react to make it 1-1.<br><br>After the equaliser, the confidence of the Indians grew and with the crowd behind them, they pushed hard for the lead.<br><br>Nine minutes later, Harmanpreet made amends for his earlier mistakes to fire a grounder past Perez to make it 2-1 as the crowd erupted in joy. The strike marked the third goal for Harmanpreet, who was being criticised for his poor penalty corner conversions in the 16-nation tournament.<br><br>--IANS<br>pur/bg<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br></p>

item.title: Benzema, Ronaldo lead Real Madrid to Club World Cup final
item.description: Yokohama (Japan), Dec 15 (IANS) Goals from Frenchman Karim Benzema and Portuguese superstar Cristiano Ronaldo helped Spanish football giants Real Madrid advance to the final of the Club World Cup, defeating Mexico's Club America 2-0 here on Thursday.
item.content: Yokohama (Japan), Dec 15 (IANS) Goals from Frenchman Karim Benzema and Portuguese superstar Cristiano Ronaldo helped Spanish football giants Real Madrid advance to the final of the Club World Cup, defeating Mexico's Club America 2-0 here on Thursday.<p><br><br>Benzema scored first from an assist executed by German Toni Kroos in the last minute of the added time of the first half. Ronaldo had several chances in the match at the International Stadium Yokohama, including a header that hit the post, reports Efe.<br><br>Ronaldo kept on wasting chances in the second half too. However, just before the final whistle, he managed to finally score from an assist by his Colombian team-mate James Rodriguez.<br><br>Madrid will be playing the final next Sunday against Japanese side Kashima Antlers, which defeated Atletico Nacional in the semi-final on Wednesday.<br><br>This is the second time Real Madrid have qualified to the Club World Cup final after 2014 in Morocco, in which they beat Argentina's San Lorenzo.<br><br>Kashima have reached the final on their first participation, becoming the first Japanese side to do so.<br><br>Club America will play for third place against Atletico Nacional next Sunday.<br><br>--IANS<br>sam/vt</p>

item.title: India beat Thailand in basketball tourney
item.description: Hong Kong, Dec 15 (IANS) India beat Thailand 86-65 to progress to the semi-finals of the 21st Super Kung Sheung Cup International Basketball Invitation Championship here on Thusday.
item.content: Hong Kong, Dec 15 (IANS) India beat Thailand 86-65 to progress to the semi-finals of the 21st Super Kung Sheung Cup International Basketball Invitation Championship here on Thusday.<p><br><br>It was yet another superlative performance by India captain Vishesh Bhriguvanshi, whose 29 points were spread out over the four quarters, and centre Amritpal Singh who had 18. Shooting guard Pratham Singh returned to form and hit double digits with 11 points.<br><br>For Thailand, Nakorn Jaisanuk (17 points) and Moses Morgan (13 points) were the star performers.<br><br>It was India's defensive work in the third period that swung the game decisively in their favour. That frame saw Thailand score only aeven points as against India's 27, which effectively sealed their fate.<br><br>The other three periods were evenly split between the sides. India won the first quarter, Thailand the second, while the fourth was an even contest.<br><br>--IANS<br>ajb/dg</p>

item.title: Mamata asks RBI Governor to disclose new notes' allocation to states (Lead)
item.description: Kolkata, Dec 15 (IANS) Expressing serious concern over alleged political discrimination among states, West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee on Thursday wrote to RBI Governor Urjit Patel to know "the nature of allocation of new currency" to each state.
item.content: Kolkata, Dec 15 (IANS) Expressing serious concern over alleged political discrimination among states, West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee on Thursday wrote to RBI Governor Urjit Patel to know "the nature of allocation of new currency" to each state.<p><br><br>Banerjee also asked the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Governor to come out with a solution so that the common people get relief from hardships following demonetisation of Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 currency notes.<br><br>In her letter to the RBI chief, Banerjee said: "We would like to know from you the nature of allocation of new currency to each of the states in a spirit of transparency and accountability, since there are serious concerns of political discrimination amongst states."<br><br>"As the Governor of the Reserve Bank of India, ... we expect you to stand up against this demonetisation onslaught against the common people of the nation at this moment of crisis, rather than falling silent and remaining opaque."<br><br>Patel held an hour-long meeting with Banerjee and the West Bengal government officials at the state Secretariat Nabanna after the apex bank's Central Board met here.<br><br>The Chief Minister described the meeting with Patel as "positive" and said she was able to put forth her views to the RBI Governor.<br><br>"He heard what I have said. What was there to answer? I have expressed the views of the common people. I have raised all the pertinent points with requisite documents and evidences."<br><br>"It was a positive meeting to express our concerns. I got an opportunity to meet the man who was involved in demonetisation. I was able to give my views and expressions on behalf of the commoners," Banerjee said.<br><br>The Chief Minister claimed in the letter that the country was going through unprecedented misery and suffering due to "cruel misadventure of demonetisation". <br><br>"We have said that you should come out with a solution. We respect the RBI as an institution, which should not be used or misused politically. The RBI must stand up and give relief to the people from the hardship they are facing," she said.<br><br>"Demonetisation was announced by the Prime Minister, not by him (RBI Governor) which was technically wrong," she contended.<br><br>The letter claimed that already five crore workers in various sectors across the country were facing unemployment and hunger, and that the unorganised sector -- which provides two-thirds of the jobs -- has "literally collapsed".<br><br>"The small and medium enterprises are shutting down in lakhs. The farmers are going through trauma due to man-made disaster of massive demonetisation," said Banerjee.<br><br>The West Bengal Chief Minister said even middle and larger industries have cut down on their production by at least 50 per cent.<br><br>Banerjee has been attacking the RBI for the way demonetisation of high-value currency notes has been implemented.<br><br>Criticising Patel's silence on the issue, she called upon the Centre and the RBI to extend a helping hand to tea garden workers who, she alleged, were dying in the aftermath of demonetisation.<br><br>The letter said the economy was getting derailed and gross domestic product growth rates were being revised down every day.<br><br>According to Banerjee, demonetisation has affected implementation of Goods and Service Tax as the state's earnings have dropped by 25 per cent due to the scrapping of high-denomination currency notes.<br><br>--IANS<br>bdc/ssp/tsb</p>

item.title: Bill moved in Lok Sabha for cashless payment of wages
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) A bill was introduced in the Lok Sabha on Thursday to amend the Payment of Wages Act to give employers the liberty to decide whether to pay wages in cash or through cheques or bank transfers.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) A bill was introduced in the Lok Sabha on Thursday to amend the Payment of Wages Act to give employers the liberty to decide whether to pay wages in cash or through cheques or bank transfers.<p><br><br>As the government is promoting cashless transactions, the Payment of Wages (Amendment) Bill will amend the 1936 act, which states that payment of wages in cheque or through bank transfer can only be made after taking the employee's permission in writing, said Labour Minister Bandaru Dattatreya.<br><br>Once the amendment bill is passed by Parliament, this authorisation will not be needed.<br><br>Stating the objects and reasons of the bill, Dattatreya said the act is being amended to enable the employer to "pay the wages to the employed person also by cheque or crediting it to their bank account".<br><br>The amendments brought by the bill will also "enable the appropriate government to specify the industrial or other establishments, by notification in the Official Gazette, which shall pay to every employed person the wages only by cheque or by crediting to his bank account".<br><br>The bill comes as Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced demonetisation of Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 currency notes on November 8. The Prime Minister is now pushing for a "cashless" economy, promoting online and other modes of transaction aiming at curbing black money.<br><br>--IANS<br>ao/vd/vt</p>

item.title: 'White wine not necessarily with white meat, ditto for red'
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Convnetional wisdom has it that while wine is to be paired with white meat and red wine with red wine. Correct? "Not so," asserts sommlier Prateek Arora.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Convnetional wisdom has it that while wine is to be paired with white meat and red wine with red wine. Correct? "Not so," asserts sommlier Prateek Arora.<p><br><br><br>"Pair a pork cooked with sage with a white wine and you get a blast of tastes," Arora told IANS at a Wine and Dine outing at the Mehrauli swish Qla fine diner here on Wednesday.<br><br>He then went a step further.<br><br>"Contrary to conventional wisdom, Indian foods and wine can be a great marriage bur certain tweaks are required to the food, The melange of spices makes this possible," Arora, a Qla director, who plays the guitar to unwind and who was named Sommlier of the Year at the recent delWine Excellance Awards, explained. <br><br>But to begin at the beginning.<br><br>"Welcome to the chemistry lab," Arora proclaimed as the guests moved into the vast bar after a rather unusual, but refreshing welcome drink - sparkling wine witn passion fruit puree and dehydrated pine apple - served in the courtyard of the 100-cover eatery, equally divided between the inside and the outside.<br><br>"To truly appreciate wine, you have to first unlearn what you know. You've gotta see if the wine talks to you. So, smell, agitate the wine and then slip slowly. Wine is all about awakening your senses," he explained.<br><br>"Wine is like a little baby trapped in a bottle. The moment the bottle opens, you are bringing out its best. Look at it, swirl it and see what it does to your nose. Taste it and it tells you what it is all about on your palette. It'll create perception areas on your tongue," Arora elaborated.<br><br>It was then time for the first of the pairings, a delicate gougeres light pastry made with three different types of cheese and chilli flakes. What the white wine did was to enhance the flavours of the cheese and sharpen the impact of the chilli flakes. Quite a combination!<br><br>It was then time to move into the kitchen where Chef Priyam Chatterjee, who was born into a family where feasts and thriving on culinary traditions were a daily deal, deftly cooked up an appetiser using shimiji mushrooms, butter, grated cheese and a variety of herbs with a generous portion of white wine.<br><br>It was then time for the sit-down part of the evening over a vegetrian white sauce risotto and (vegetarian/non-vegetarian red sauce pasta - served in tandem with a white an a red wine.<br><br>That proved quite a momement as the red wine, which went down smoothly when sipped independently, tasted a mite sweet when combined with the two dishes - proof of wine creating "perception areas" on the tongue.<br><br><br>"I'm absolutely passionate about wine," said Arora, who explained that he uses his wine palate to deconstruct and construct drinks to do justice to each ingredient which, according to him, should shine through in what a guest gets in the glass. For him, each of the parts is as important as the whole. <br><br>And this is what prompted him to lauch the Wednesday Wine Evening at Qla once a month.<br><br>"We choose the dates with care to ensure they don't clash with anything important. We want our guests to spend a quiet evening and not get hassled about being caught in traffic or any other eventuality," Arora concluded. <br><br>(Vishnu Makhijani visited Qla at the reataurant's invitation. He can be contacted at vishnu.makhijani@ians.in)<br><br>--IANS<br>vm</p>

item.title: India distances itself from Russia's Taliban comment
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) India on Thursday distanced itself from a reported comment of Russia's Ambassador to Afghanistan that his country and Taliban shared interests in fighting the Islamic State terror outfit.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) India on Thursday distanced itself from a reported comment of Russia's Ambassador to Afghanistan that his country and Taliban shared interests in fighting the Islamic State terror outfit.<p><br><br>"We do not comment on relationship between third countries," Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) spokesperson Vikas Swaroop told reporters here.<br><br>Russia's Ambassador to Afghanistan Alexander Mantytskiy told the Afghan Parliament over the weekend that Zamir Kabulov, a high ranking official in Russia's Foreign Ministry, has said that "our interests are the same as Taliban in fighting" the Islamic State.<br><br>Commenting on apprehensions that it might lead to complications in India's relations with Russia, Swarup said ties between the two nations are a "special and privileged partnership" which was reinforced by the recent visit of Russian President Vladimir Putin to Goa in October.<br><br>"We do not see any downward trend in our bilateral relationship," he said. <br><br>The spokesperson, however, said as far as the Taliban is concerned, "they have to respect the internationally agreed red lines, give up terrorism and violence, sever all ties with Al Qaeda, agree to follow democratic norms and not do anything which will erode the gains of the last 15 years." <br><br>"Ultimately it is for the government of Afghanistan to decide whom to talk to and how," he said on whether the Afghanistan regime should talk to the Taliban.<br><br>--IANS<br>sk/sar/vt</p>

item.title: Galaxy of stars in PWL auction (Preview)
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) A total of 30 Olympic and World Championship medallists will go under the hammer at the second Pro Wrestling League (PWL) player auction to be held here on Friday.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) A total of 30 Olympic and World Championship medallists will go under the hammer at the second Pro Wrestling League (PWL) player auction to be held here on Friday.<p><br><br>Besides, 92 Indian wrestlers including 2016 Rio Olympics bronze medallist Sakshi Malik will also test the waters in a closed bid. <br><br>"Approximately 200 Indian and foreign players are participating in auction this year including 107 foreign and 92 Indian wrestlers. I am happy that the Indian players will get the opportunity to compete with global players. Vladimer Khinchegashvili of Georgia, Haji Aliyev from Azerbaijan, Ukraine's Oksana Herhel and Erica Wiebe will be the main highlights among the foreigners," Wrestling Federation of India (WFI) President Brijbhushan Sharan Singh said in a statement. <br><br>"There will be tough competition among Rio silver medallist Maria Mamashuk of Belarus, Olympic bronze medallist Tunisia' Marwa Amri, Yulia Ratkevich of Azerbaijan, Ukraine's Yulia Tkach and 10 Indian players including Sakshi Malik and Geeta Phogat in the 58 kilogram weight category.<br><br>"Yulia Ratkevich and Yulia Tkach are current World Championships bronze medallists. On the other hand seven Indian players including Ritu Phogat will compete with three times Olympic medallist Mariya Stadnik of Azerbaijan, Olympic bronze medallist Bulgaria's Elista Yankova. There are seven Indian players in the same weight category," he added. <br><br>"In the women's super heavyweight category, Canada's Erica Wiebe, Rio bronze medallist Sweden's Jenny Frensn, World Championship bronze medallist Vasilisa Marzaliuk of Belarus will be the main highlights.<br><br>Among the men, all eyes will be on London Olympics bronze medallist Yogeshwar Dutt, Asian champion Sandeep Tomar, World Championship medallists Bajrang Punia and Amit Dahiya along with Commonwealth Games silver medallist Satyawart Kadian. <br><br>--IANS<br>ajb/bg</p>

item.title: PAN must for 'small accounts' if deposits exceed Rs 2 lakh, balance Rs 5 lakh
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The RBI on Thursday said it will be mandatory for banks to take the PAN of holders of small accounts, or those opened by submitting the holder's photograph and affixing signature or thumb impression in a bank official's presence, where deposits after demonetisation have exceeded Rs 2 lakh and the total balance is Rs 5 lakh.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) The RBI on Thursday said it will be mandatory for banks to take the PAN of holders of small accounts, or those opened by submitting the holder's photograph and affixing signature or thumb impression in a bank official's presence, where deposits after demonetisation have exceeded Rs 2 lakh and the total balance is Rs 5 lakh.<p><br><br>The banks and Non-banking Financial Companies have to ensure compliance towards Know your customer (KYC), including quoting of PAN or obtaining of Form 60 for accounts where "balance is Rs 5 lakh or more and the total deposits (including credits by electronic or other means) made after November 9, 2016, exceed Rs 2 lakh".<br><br>The small accounts will thus be converted into normal accounts, said the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).<br><br>"No debit transaction, transfer or otherwise shall be allowed in accounts which do not comply with these requirements," RBI said in a statement. <br><br>These accounts have certain limitations such as balance in such accounts at any point of time should not exceed Rs 50,000, total credits in one year should not exceed Rs 1 lakh and total withdrawal and transfers in a month should not exceed Rs 10,000.<br><br>Such accounts remain operational initially for a period of twelve months and thereafter, for a further period of twelve months if the account holder provides evidence of having applied for officially valid documents.<br><br>--IANS<br>mm/vd</p>

item.title: Poll dates not finalised, still at planning stage: CEC
item.description: Panaji, Dec 15 (IANS) The Election Commission of India is still at the "planning stage" as far as finalisation of dates for the upcoming state assembly elections to five states, Chief Election Commissioner Nasim Zaidi said on Thursday.
item.content: Panaji, Dec 15 (IANS) The Election Commission of India is still at the "planning stage" as far as finalisation of dates for the upcoming state assembly elections to five states, Chief Election Commissioner Nasim Zaidi said on Thursday.<p><br><br>"We are still at a planning stage. We are taking a number of inputs regarding availability of security forces and various other factors like examinations. We are in consultation with various (Education) boards. <br><br>"We are also looking into climatological factors in and many other things like level of preparedness, etc," Zaidi told reporters after reviewing poll preparations in Goa, which along with Punjab, Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand and Manipur are expected to go to polls early next year.<br><br>"The Commission will not be able to tell you scheduling, phasing etc at this point in time," he also said.<br><br>--IANS<br>maya/vd</p>

item.title: Amrinder, Manpreet in Congress first list for Punjab polls
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Punjab Congress chief Captain Amarinder Singh and former Finance Minister Manpreet Singh Badal are among the 61 candidates announced by the party on Thursday in its first list for the upcoming assembly elections.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Punjab Congress chief Captain Amarinder Singh and former Finance Minister Manpreet Singh Badal are among the 61 candidates announced by the party on Thursday in its first list for the upcoming assembly elections.<p><br><br>While Amarinder Ssingh will contest from Patiala, Manpreet Badal will fight from Bathinda Urban. The party, in its first list, has retained 31 sitting MLAs. <br><br>Meanwhile, cricketer-turned-politician Navjot Singh Sidhu's wife Navjot Kaur Sidhu's name is not there.<br><br>Among other prominent figures in the list are Charanjit Channi, the sitting MLA from Chamkaur Sahib (SC), Rajinder Kaur Bhattal from Lehra, Sunil Jakhar from Abohar, and O.P. Soni from Amritsar Central.<br><br>The name of former Lok Sabha MP Vijay Inder Singla is also there. He will contest from Sangrur, from where he lost the poll for the parliamentary constituency of the same name in the 2014 general elections.<br><br>The list was released by party General Secretary Madhusudan Mistry.<br><br>--IANS<br>sid/vd</p>

item.title: Pakistan gets first organ transplant centre
item.description: Islamabad, Dec 15 (IANS) Pakistan has got its first organ transplant centre at the Sindh Institute of Urology and Transplantation (SIUT) that will provide facilities for multi-organ transplants, including for liver, intestine, pancreas, bone marrow and cornea.
item.content: Islamabad, Dec 15 (IANS) Pakistan has got its first organ transplant centre at the Sindh Institute of Urology and Transplantation (SIUT) that will provide facilities for multi-organ transplants, including for liver, intestine, pancreas, bone marrow and cornea.<p><br><br>The 14-storey facility, inaugurated on Wednesday, is designed to meet the future challenges of transplantation science, the Dawn reported on Thursday. <br><br>Spread over an area of 250,000 square feet, the 100-bed transplant centre has intensive care units, transplant wards and a state-of-the-art modern operation theatre -- all under one roof.<br><br>--IANS<br>soni/sar/vt</p>

item.title: Parliament's winter session headed for washout (Roundup)
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Parliament's winter session -- which ends on December 16 -- is headed for a virtual washout as chaos reigned in both houses on Thursday, the penultimate day of the month-long session.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Parliament's winter session -- which ends on December 16 -- is headed for a virtual washout as chaos reigned in both houses on Thursday, the penultimate day of the month-long session.<p><br><br>Members of both the opposition and treasury benches indulged in recrimination over demonetisation, corruption and other issues. <br><br>In the Lok Sabha, the opposition pressed for a debate on demonetisation while the treasury benches demanded a discussion on the AgustaWestland helicopter deal.<br><br>The continued disruption in both the houses angered veteran Bharatiya Janata Party leader and Lok Sabha member L.K. Advani, who said he feels like resigning from Parliament because of unending pandemonium.<br><br>He asked Home Minister Rajnath Singh to convey to Speaker Sumitra Mahajan that she should ensure that the house functions on Friday to discuss the November 8 demonetisation.<br><br>In the Lok Sabha, both opposition and treasury benches shouted at each other as Speaker Sumitra Mahajan warned the members against displaying newspapers in the house. She then adjourned the house till noon. <br><br>The opposition accused the Bharatiya Janata Party members of obstructing the debate.<br><br>Telangana Rashtra Samithi leader A.P. Jithender Reddy said he should be allowed to speak as he had started the discussion on demonetisation under Rule 193.<br><br>"Every party has a problem with the implementation of demonetisation... I was not allowed to speak," Reddy said.<br><br>Trinamool Congress leader Sudip Bandyopadhyay said, "There is one more day left before the end of the session. A discussion could have been initiated, without any rules."<br><br>Parliamentary Affairs Minister H.N. Ananth Kumar raised the issue of the AgustaWestland VVIP helicopter deal and said names of certain Congress leaders are mentioned in middleman Christian Michel's diary.<br><br>This further irked the opposition members, leading to more ruckus, following which Speaker Sumitra Mahajan adjourned the house for the day.<br><br>Even after the Lok Sabha was adjourned, Advani remained seated while other members left the house.<br><br>From the media gallery, Advani was heard telling Rajnath Singh to convey to the Speaker that she should ensure the house runs on Friday to discuss demonetisation.<br><br>Advani was then joined by Trinamool Congress MP Idris Ali, who later told reporters that he asked after the former Deputy Prime Minister's health, to which the latter quipped: "My health is fine but the health of Parliament is not."<br><br>"I feel like resigning," said Advani, his comments audible to those present in the media gallery.<br><br>Idris then asked Advani about Vajpayee's health. Advani replied: "He would have been very sad to see this."<br><br>"If the situation is the same on the last day as well, Parliament will be slandered," Advani said.<br><br>"Such a thing has never happened in the House of Commons... adjourned for no reason. I feel ashamed," he added.<br><br>In the Rajya Sabha, similar acrimonious scenes were witnessed. It was first adjourned till noon amid chaos, minutes after it re-assembled following a four-day break on account of week-end and two holidays.<br><br>Soon after the house met for the day, the Chair allowed Leader of Opposition Ghulam Nabi Azad to speak but members from the treasury benches did not let him speak.<br><br>"This should also go on record that in both the houses, it is the ruling party (BJP) that is not allowing any work," Azad said, adding that it was happening for the "first time in the history of India".<br><br>Deputy Chairman P.J. Kurien kept on urging protesting members to maintain peace but his pleas went unheeded.<br><br>"Why should both sides create problem? I don't know," he said and adjourned the house till noon.<br><br>Later, the house was adjourned for 30 minutes and then again till 2 p.m. It was finally adjourned for the day after 2 p.m. as the opposition members demanded a debate on demonetisation and plight of farmers while those on the treasury benches sought a debate on the AgustaWestland chopper deal.<br><br>The winter session of Parliament started on November 16 but has been washed away due to protests over the government's November 8 demonetisation and other issues.<br><br>--IANS<br>bns/tsb/vt</p>

item.title: The nine-year-old \'Google\' boy who even leaves experts impressed
item.description: Patna, Dec 15 (IANS) At an age when most children are only engaged in games and playing, this nine-year-old knows all about the planet Mars. Meet Kautilya whose prodigious knowledge, comprehension and sharp memory is the envy of even those much ahead in age and qualification.
item.content: Patna, Dec 15 (IANS) At an age when most children are only engaged in games and playing, this nine-year-old knows all about the planet Mars. Meet Kautilya whose prodigious knowledge, comprehension and sharp memory is the envy of even those much ahead in age and qualification.<p><br><br>Here with his father and grandfather on Thursday to meet mathematician and Super 30 founder Anand Kumar, Kautilya left him most impressed by his knowledge, and confidence in talking as an near-equal in age. According to his grand father J.K. Sharma, it was his desire to take Kautilya to Anand Kumar so that he could assess the boy\'s capabilities and guide him for the future. \"What Anand has achieved, very few can match. He himself is exceptional and thus we felt that this exceptional child should get his blessings. We have come to Patna just for this purpose,\" Sharma said. Kautilya also interacted with Super 30 students, who comprise carefully selected aspirants from disadvantaged sections undergoing intense training for the IIT entrance exams, and media persons. \"These days, I am studying about astronomy and I want to become an astro scientist in life,\" said Kautilya, a class 5 student at Bhavan Vidyalaya, Panchkula (near Chandigarh), but capable of reeling out statistics, geographical locations and trivia as well as mathematical calculations as if all the information has been fed into him. He has all the updateS about the ongoing researches on planet Mars. \"He is like that since the time he was a toddler. He was always curious with abundant questions to ask on everything he came across,\" said his grandfather, who approached psychologists at the Kurukshetra University to find about his immense curiosity and interests. Kautilya\'s exceptionally high IQ level was discovered at the university where psychology professors advised his family to pay special attention to him and ensure his distinguished skills and talent are not dissipated. \"It was his remarkable quality that got him on the Kaun Banega Crorepati television show on the Children\'s Day,\" said his father Satish Sharma, who runs a private school in the village. \"Later Bachchanji also tweeted about how much he was impressed by the wunderkid for his knowledge that defied his age,\" he added. Anand Kumar said that Kautilya was certainly different from children of his age and displayed striking knowledge and confidence. \"He needs to be carefully nurtured with a lot of freedom to do what he loves. I had also heard of him and will extend whatever help Kautilya will require,\" he said, adding he wished him great success. --IANS mg/vd</p>

item.title: Ranji: Odisha shot out for 152 by Jharkhand
item.description: Thumba (Kerala), Dec 15 (IANS) Odisha were bowled out for 152 runs by Jharkhand on the opening day of their Group B clash here on Thursday.
item.content: Thumba (Kerala), Dec 15 (IANS) Odisha were bowled out for 152 runs by Jharkhand on the opening day of their Group B clash here on Thursday.<p><br><br>Odisha slumped to the low score at the St Xavier's College Ground due to a combination of slack batting and disciplined bowling.<br><br>Jharkhand won the toss and elected to field and the decision was vindicated by left-arm spinner Shahbaz Nadeem (4/31) and off-spinner Sunny Gupta (3/56), who were the chief wicket takers, bundling out Odisha in 84 overs.<br><br>In reply, Jharkhand's openers Anand Singh and Sumit Kumar saw off the four remaining overs, scoring 9/0.<br><br>Sandeep Pattnaik (43) was the highest scorer for Odisha, followed by his opening partner Ranjit Singh (20).<br><br>They put on 46 for the first wicket stand but after Ranjit's departure in the 28th over, their innings fell apart as they lost wickets at regular intervals, ultimately folding for a very low score.<br><br>Brief scores: Odisha first innings 152 (Sandeep Pattnaik 43, Ranjit Singh 20, Shahbaz Nadeem 4/31, Sunny Gupta 3/56)<br><br>--IANS<br>sam/bg</p>

item.title: Smith ton boosts Australia on first day vs Pakistan
item.description: Brisbane, Dec 15 (IANS) Steven Smith scored a century to place Australia in a strong position at the end of the opening day of the first cricket Test against Pakistan here on Thursday.
item.content: Brisbane, Dec 15 (IANS) Steven Smith scored a century to place Australia in a strong position at the end of the opening day of the first cricket Test against Pakistan here on Thursday.<p><br><br>Smith was batting on 110 at stumps with Peter Handscomb also in good form at the other end. The hosts were on 288/3 at the close.<br><br>Smith's 192-ball innings included 16 boundaries. Handscomb's 64 runs came off 150 deliveries with eight hits to the fence.<br><br>For Pakistan, Mohammad Amir, Wahab Riaz and Yasir Shah bagged a wicket each.<br><br>Electing to bat on winning the toss, Australia were off to a good start with Matt Renshaw and David Warner producing an opening stand of 70 runs.<br><br>Warner scored 32 runs before being trapped leg before by Amir.<br><br>Usman Khawaja lasted just seven balls before stepping out to Yasir only to find Misbah-ul Haq at short midwicket.<br><br>The two quick wickets may have given the Pakistanis a glimmer of hope which was quickly diminished by a 76-run partnership between Smith and Renshaw.<br><br>Riaz brought the partnership to an end when Renshaw nicked one to wicketkeeper Sarfraz Ahmed when on 71.<br><br>Handscomb then joined Smith in the middle and the duo proceeded to add 137 runs between them to help the hosts end the opening day on a strong note.<br><br>Brief scores:<br> <br>Australia: 288/3 (Steven Smith 110 batting, Peter Handscomb 64 batting, Matt Renshaw 71) vs Pakistan.<br><br>--IANS<br>ajb/dg</p>

item.title: Keep bureaucracy away from politics, Union minister tells AAP
item.description: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Union Minister Harsh Vardhan on Thursday said the Aam Aadmi Party government in Delhi should keep bureaucracy away from its politics.
item.content: New Delhi, Dec 15 (IANS) Union Minister Harsh Vardhan on Thursday said the Aam Aadmi Party government in Delhi should keep bureaucracy away from its politics.<p><br><br>"The AAP government must keep the bureaucracy away from its politics. Harassing it will further stall work in the NCR (National Capital Region), making people suffer because of this circus," Harsh Vardhan said in a tweet.<br><br>"IAS officers (AGMUT, DANICS) appeal to the Delhi government to refrain from misdemeanour, fake allegations, misinformation campaign etc.," he wrote in another tweet.<br><br>The Union Science and Technology Minister's remarks came a day after Delhi Deputy Chief Minister Manish Sisodia slammed two bodies -- AGMUT (Arunachal Pradesh, Goa, Mizoram and Union Territories) IAS Association and DANICS (Delhi and Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Lakshadweep, Daman and Diu, and Dadra and Nagar Haveli Civil Service) Association -- saying that they have become "politicised and are passing politically-motivated" resolutions.<br><br>Sisodia warned the bureaucrats of "strict action" if they refused to work for public welfare.<br><br>The two bodies had jointly passed a resolution on Tuesday against the alleged injustices meted out by the political executive of the Delhi government.<br><br>--IANS<br>aks/bns/tsb/vt</p>

item.title: Congress condemns move to withdraw Tarun Gogoi's NSG cover
item.description: Guwahati, Dec 15 (IANS) The opposition Congress in Assam has condemned the move to withdraw National Security Guards (NSG) security cover of former Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi and termed it politically motivated.
item.content: Guwahati, Dec 15 (IANS) The opposition Congress in Assam has condemned the move to withdraw National Security Guards (NSG) security cover of former Assam Chief Minister Tarun Gogoi and termed it politically motivated.<p><br><br>Sources close to Gogoi said on Thursday that the three-time Assam Chief Minister has received a letter from the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) conveying to him the decision to withdraw the NSG security cover. <br><br>There is, however, no mention about the Z+ security cover, to which the former Assam Chief Minister is entitled.<br><br>Assam Pradesh Congress Committee (APCC) president and Rajya Sabha MP Ripun Bora condemned the central government's move and said it shows the Bharatiya Janata Party's vindictiveness.<br><br>"This is unwarranted. This should not have happened. It is only six months that the former Chief Minister had left his office and the threat perception is still there. If something happens to him, the Ministry of Home Affairs will be responsible," Bora said.<br><br>Leader of the Opposition in the Assam Legislative Assembly Debabrata Saikia also condemned the move and said it is a motivated move by the government to silence Gogoi.<br><br>"We have seen that the former Chief Minister had been very vocal against the ruling government against all its wrong decisions and anti-people policies. Now the state government has taken a calculated move to silence Gogoi by withdrawing the NSG security cover," Saikia said. <br><br>"We condemn this decision of the government," he added.<br><br>A senior official of Assam police, however, said the police are yet to receive any instructions in this regard. <br><br>"However, in case the central government has decided to withdraw the NSG security cover, Gogoi will continue to get the security cover according to the Z+ category protocol," he said.<br><br>Apart from Gogoi, former Assam Chief Minister Prafulla Kumar Mahanta is entitled to NSG security cover. <br><br>Assam Chief Minister Sarbananda Sonowal is entitled to Z+ security cover only and his security is provided by the state police commandos. <br><br>Although Assam police recommended NSG security cover for Sonowal, it is yet to be cleared by the Ministry of Home Affairs.<br><br>--IANS<br>ah/pgh/bg</p>

item.title: Europe calls on Germany to compensate victims of Thalidomide
item.description: Strasbourg, Dec 15 (IANS) Europe on Thursday passed a non-binding resolution calling on Germany to compensate all European victims of the drug thalidomide, which caused deformities in thousands of children in the late 1950s and early 1960s.
